p.s: Amir KarootKapoor is the protagonist of the play Disgraced, Scene 3.
He is a Pakistani American about 40 and works as a lawyer.
He lives in an apartment in the Upper East Side of New York with his wife Emily, who is an artist, being fascinated by Islamic culture and traditions.
His biggest fear is discrimminationdiscrimination and therefore changes his name and doesn't talk openly about his ethnicity.
He has been raised as a Muslim but isn't a fan of it.
He thinks that Islam espouses wife-beathing and antisemitsmantisemitism.
In scene 3 Amir gets confronted with a lot of not so pleasing suprisessurprises, which exposes the hidden part of his character.
Amir suffers of anger issues and tends ot handle his problems with violence (p. 72, ll. 33, 29).
He starts by being verbally aggressive, calling Isaac an asshole (ll. 33) and offending or even discrimminatingdiscriminating Jory by saying the n-word (ll. 29).
But it doesn't stick to verbal aggresivenessaggressiveness.

After having a huge discussion about Islam, finding out about Jory taking his job and knowing his wife is cheating on him with Isaac, Amir loses his controllcontrol and starts being physically aggressive as well by beating Emily multiple times until she starts bleeding (p. 74, ll. 4, 6-9).
He also spits Isaac in the face after verbally offending him (p. 72, ll. 40) and provokes him (p. 72, ll. 35).
This kind of behavior shows that he can't handle stress.
In addition with (the) overstimulation he loses his controllcontrol and freaks out.
It seems like he is paralyzed while beating Emily, because he doesn't realize it in the moment and doesn't stoppstop hurting her (p. 74, ll. 15).
Another reason for him feeling overstimulated is the fact that Jory steals his job.
This action proves his thoughts about racism at work, even though Jory is black.

All this time he was hiding his identity for his safety and well-being, but ending up destroying his life by that, because his boss thinks he's duplicitous (p. 73, ll. 7) after finding out about his real name and ethnicity.
He questions his loyalty and therefore doesn't trust him with the job (p. 73, ll. 7-9).

Because of this explanation (for not getting the job) Amir re-realizes that his identity is part of who he is and effects his opportunities of being successfullsuccessful, which (perhaps, for sure) makes him feel even more frustrated and ashamed of himself and his background.
Furthermore Amir behaves extremlyextremely nervous and overwhelmed because he sways from side to side and withdraws himself for a moment p. 73, ll. 16-17, 23.
A reason for this behavior could be that it's his real first time letting his emotions and feelings come to the surface.
He isn't used to that and because of that he loses his controllcontrol and gets aggressive in any kind of way.
But on the other side it can also mean that he can't believe what happened, especially the affair his wife has with Isaac.
He can't imagine Emily, betrainingbetraying him, like that and needs his time to realize what just has happened (p. 73, ll. 22-24, p. 71, ll. 31).
All in all Amir's character and behavior towards Islam, his friends, and own ethnicity show what deep effects racism has on affected people.
On the other hand it also shows the danger of denying one's identity and suppressing emotions and feelings.
